quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: People often think that I get hired into later stage companies because I'm supposed to teach them how to operate like a big company, and in fact, I say I'm hired to remind them they can operate like a startup.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A contrarian leadership framing: later-stage companies often need startup speed and mindset more than additional process.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I communicate to my leaders that my expectation is they bring in the clock speed one click faster. If you think something needs to be done this year, it needs to be done this half.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete operating mechanism for increasing pace by systematically compressing timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'm using CPTO for short code of running product and engineering design functionally together. There should be no debates over what's best for product or what's best for engineering, what's best for design speed. What is best for the organization?
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A unifying org model and decision principle that replaces functional tradeoffs with an organization-level optimization lens.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Is it going to eliminate PMs next year? Probably not. Are the skills required going to shift? Yes. Could they shift much faster than we all anticipate? Probably.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A pragmatic AI forecast that emphasizes rapid skill shifts over near-term job elimination, prompting proactive upskilling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: As a business, you care about revenue, but as a product team, the last thing you want to do is delay a product launch or a pricing change because your team has to rebuild billing from scratch.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Orb)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical tradeoff: billing complexity can directly slow down launches and pricing iteration, so teams should avoid rebuilding billing in-house.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Orb is a flexible usage-based billing engine that lets you evolve your pricing with ease.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Orb)
quotes.context: Frames billing infrastructure as an enabler of rapid pricing experimentation and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Probably, because the sad truth is that most SaaS features are rarely or never used, costing the industry billions every year.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Dovetail)
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that shipping more features often creates waste, motivating stronger customer-insight practices.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over one day in San Francisco, the product community is coming together to learn how to better leverage customer insights and build products that people actually love to use.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Dovetail)
quotes.context: Emphasizes an actionable product principle: systematically leverage customer insights to drive adoption and love, not just output.

quotes.topic_title: Career progression: clarity, asking, making it easy
quotes.text: But when it comes to career growth and that progression from, I actually started as a copywriter of all things, copywriter all the way up to a CPO or CPTO that runs an engineering organization, it boils down to something really simple, which is know what you want out of your career, be clear and ask for it, and then make it easy for your boss or whoever can support or champion you to get you from here to there.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable framework for accelerating career progression: clarity, direct asking, and reducing friction for decision-makers.

quotes.topic_title: Career progression: clarity, asking, making it easy
quotes.text: And I sat for about a half a day and I thought, I think I can help here, drew out an org chart, put my name on the top, walked into my boss's office and said, "This is one potential solve of your marketing organization question, is we'll bring product and marketing growth together. I can be in this position. Here's how I'd change the management structure underneath this. Not just where do you put me, but where do you put everybody else? And I think this could work for the company, and this is how I'd suggest we roll it out and this would be my JD." And I got that job.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete example of “make it easy to say yes” by proposing the full solution (org chart + rollout + JD), not just asking for a promotion.

quotes.topic_title: Career progression: clarity, asking, making it easy
quotes.text: The other thing that I give people advice about is know what you want out of your current role and know exactly what you want your next role to be.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical planning heuristic: explicitly define both the value you want now and the specific next step you’re aiming for.

quotes.topic_title: Career progression: clarity, asking, making it easy
quotes.text: Now, I think there's a fine balance here. There's one thing to be very clear about your goals. It's another to suck the oxygen out of the air about only talking about getting promoted. These are probably 0.005% of my interactions with my boss are about my career growth and my path. It's very small. "Am I clear? Are we on the same page? And am I communicating as I'm making progress against those goals?"
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance on promotion conversations: align explicitly but keep it a tiny fraction of interactions, focusing day-to-day on execution and progress.

quotes.topic_title: Career progression: clarity, asking, making it easy
quotes.text: I've almost never wished I promoted somebody earlier.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A manager’s perspective that challenges the common belief that high performers are usually “promoted too late,” emphasizing readiness and org timing.

quotes.topic_title: Promotion balance: timing, norms, and company needs
quotes.text: One, you've got to lock to the norms, the talent norms of your organization. You should know how those things work, and they can work very casually if you're a very small startup and they can work more formally if you're at a very large company.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to align promotion expectations and approach to the specific promotion mechanics and norms of your company’s size and structure.

quotes.topic_title: Promotion balance: timing, norms, and company needs
quotes.text: And one, understanding how promotions operationally happen inside an organization can help you have those conversations at the right time in the right moment with the right context.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat promotions as an operational process with timing and context, not just a performance outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Promotion balance: timing, norms, and company needs
quotes.text: I think the second thing is really the conversation needs to be about what you being in a different position does for the company and why the company needs it.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Reframes promotion discussions from personal ambition to business need, increasing the odds of a productive outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Promotion balance: timing, norms, and company needs
quotes.text: That's solving a problem for the company. That's not solving a career growth issue for an individual.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Memorable distinction that helps practitioners position promotion asks as organizational problem-solving rather than entitlement.

quotes.topic_title: Promotion balance: timing, norms, and company needs
quotes.text: So, there aren't just management and director and senior director roles to go around. And if you want to get into a management, for example, you have to prove that you're good at organization design.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that management promotion requires demonstrating org design capability, not just individual performance.

quotes.topic_title: Expanding scope: leading engineering and going sideways
quotes.text: PM is such a generalist role, it's okay to go a little left and a little right to go up.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A memorable career-growth framework for PMs: expand scope laterally (marketing, ops, etc.) as a path to senior leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Expanding scope: leading engineering and going sideways
quotes.text: I knew there was a problem to solve. I knew that problem was important. I knew we had to solve it fast, and I was confident I knew I could do it.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical checklist for when to raise your hand for bigger scope: importance, urgency, and personal confidence in execution.

quotes.topic_title: Expanding scope: leading engineering and going sideways
quotes.text: And one of the other things that I think people don't understand, and maybe I experienced this as a founder and I really feel it inside companies, is the universe is bendable to your will.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A contrarian mindset shift: org structures aren’t fixed, so you can shape roles and scope by proposing solutions to real needs.

quotes.topic_title: Expanding scope: leading engineering and going sideways
quotes.text: organizations are very fluid and I like to organize around talented motivated individuals.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A leadership/org-design principle that explains how to create new opportunities: build teams and scope around high-agency people.

quotes.topic_title: Expanding scope: leading engineering and going sideways
quotes.text: I took this marketing growth role. That was actually my first director role. It wasn't only for product, it was for marketing.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete example of “going sideways” (into marketing) to unlock a higher-level title and broader leadership trajectory.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding overload: zone of genius and sustainability
quotes.text: I truly believe defining and understanding your zone of genius, where you are exceptional, where no one else can step into the job and do just as good of a job as you can, and where you derive tremendous intellectual emotional joy out of the work is what makes it sustainable over time.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Defines a practical “zone of genius” framework for choosing work that remains sustainable and high-impact.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding overload: zone of genius and sustainability
quotes.text: And so I don't actually think it's about the volume or breadth of the work. It's about sustainability of the work. And can you show up every day energized and engaged and excited about what you do?
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Reframes overload from “too much work” to “unsustainable work,” offering a diagnostic question for day-to-day energy.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding overload: zone of genius and sustainability
quotes.text: I have never regretted promoting somebody too slowly, I have regretted promoting somebody too quickly.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for managers to avoid over-scoping high-potential people into roles where they struggle and burn out.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding overload: zone of genius and sustainability
quotes.text: Individually, I do do a lot, but I do feel like I'm in my zone of genius and I also know that part of staying in my personal zone of genius is having this breadth of responsibility but preserving builder time.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Introduces “preserving builder time” as a concrete tactic for maintaining effectiveness even with broad scope.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding overload: zone of genius and sustainability
quotes.text: And what I mean from time is I have to have time to produce real work that comes from me as an individual, and that means that calendar management is quite important. Time management.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Connects protecting maker/builder time to calendar discipline as an actionable operational practice.

quotes.topic_title: Finding your zone of genius
quotes.text: Yeah. I'm not going to relay it in precision, but one of the tactics that I've seen out there is basically go through your calendar for the last month or quarter, whatever it is, write everything down, and basically group them into, I hated doing this, I didn't love doing it but it was fine, I love doing this, and then I love doing this, and if I could spend all my time on this, I would be the happiest person in the whole world.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical “energy audit” method for identifying the work that most reliably signals your zone of genius.

quotes.topic_title: Finding your zone of genius
quotes.text: And literally categorize the way you're spending your time into those buckets, and then put the bottom buckets away. Just focus on that top bucket and go, "How can I be here more?"
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Clear prioritization guidance: reduce low-energy work and intentionally design your schedule around the highest-energy activities.

quotes.topic_title: Finding your zone of genius
quotes.text: I think the other thing is really asking yourself, and this maybe goes back to the career advice perspective, really asking yourself, "What do I do that no one else in this organization can do?"
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A differentiation question that reframes career growth around unique, hard-to-replicate value rather than general competence.

quotes.topic_title: Finding your zone of genius
quotes.text: I feel like I have a high level of fluency broadly and can bring conversations between functions together against a business objective pretty easily.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete example of a “zone of genius” advantage: cross-functional fluency that aligns teams around outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Finding your zone of genius
quotes.text: And so, yes, I love to be up here and think about strategy and vision, but I also like to drop into the details to move things forward.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A memorable model of “traversing elevation” that links strategic thinking with execution by moving between levels of abstraction.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast at scale: clock speed and SLAs
quotes.text: I often find that pace of organization locks to pace of the calendar, and so I am really thoughtful that reoccurring meetings do not drive next steps.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical warning against letting meeting cadence dictate execution speed, pushing teams to decouple action from calendars.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast at scale: clock speed and SLAs
quotes.text: when somebody says, "Oh, we'll discuss this or we'll decide this in the next meeting," it's, "No, we should discuss this now. We should decide this tomorrow."
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete behavioral rule for accelerating decisions by defaulting to immediate discussion and near-term decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast at scale: clock speed and SLAs
quotes.text: I communicate to my leaders that my expectation is they bring in the clock speed one click faster, which means if you think something needs to be done this year, it needs to be done this half. If you think it needs to be done this half, it needs to be done this quarter. This quarter, this month. This week, today. End of day, in this meeting.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A memorable, repeatable framework (“one click faster”) for systematically pulling timelines forward across an organization.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast at scale: clock speed and SLAs
quotes.text: The third thing on pace is personal SLA. I never want to be a bottleneck for the organization.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A leadership operating principle: set a fast personal response/decision SLA so the org’s speed isn’t capped by you.

quotes.topic_title: Moving fast at scale: clock speed and SLAs
quotes.text: That is an artificial timeline introduced by Google Calendar or whatever calendar you use. It's not a real thing, and so I want to put us on real timelines.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges “next meeting” as a default and replaces it with decision timelines based on actual needs.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a high bar: talent standards and candid feedback
quotes.text: You have to define the bar. You have to be really specific, and that means you have to think about pretty deeply what are your leadership principles?
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical leadership standard-setting framework: start by explicitly defining principles and expectations rather than relying on implicit norms.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a high bar: talent standards and candid feedback
quotes.text: And so I do think it's really important to have a specific and measurable career ladder, especially at the senior levels.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Actionable advice to make senior-level expectations measurable so performance can be assessed clearly and consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a high bar: talent standards and candid feedback
quotes.text: And Brené Brown, fellow Texan, love her, "Clear is kind," I think conflict-avoidant, feedback-avoidant cultures degrade the talent bar.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A memorable mental model linking candid feedback to maintaining high talent standards—and warning that avoidance lowers the bar.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a high bar: talent standards and candid feedback
quotes.text: I called both of them individually and I said, "The way you are operating is not meeting our leadership expectations. If you do not change, you cannot be part of this organization anymore. I believe you can operate differently. I do."
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete example of direct expectation-resetting that combines accountability with belief in the person’s ability to improve.

quotes.topic_title: Keeping a high bar: talent standards and candid feedback
quotes.text: And I honestly think saying, "You are not doing a good job," is much kinder than, "I think you can improve on this aspect or that aspect."
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take: blunt clarity can be more humane than softened feedback because it enables real course correction.

quotes.topic_title: Being a woman in tech: realities and leverage points
quotes.text: And what I want to be clear about, because it gets talked about a lot in forms like this, this is not about imposter syndrome.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Reframes a common narrative by separating confidence/self-doubt from structural bias, which changes what interventions actually help.

quotes.topic_title: Being a woman in tech: realities and leverage points
quotes.text: And the way I approach it is I'm just very curious. I wonder what is structural about technology that creates these things happen? What is cultural? What is external? What has happened to me or happens around me? What is internal? What do I bring into the room that doesn't serve me?
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Offers a practical diagnostic framework (structural/cultural/external/internal) for analyzing bias and deciding what to change vs. ignore.

quotes.topic_title: Being a woman in tech: realities and leverage points
quotes.text: And then constant product thinker, what are the points of leverage I can use to move things not just forward for me, but for the industry broadly? How can I influence thinking? Where can I not? Where can I walk away from things?
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Turns a difficult reality into an actionable “leverage points” method: identify influenceable surfaces and explicitly choose when to disengage.

quotes.topic_title: Being a woman in tech: realities and leverage points
quotes.text: I consistently get asked if I'm technical enough. Not even if I'm technical enough. Let's put enough aside. If I'm technical.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A vivid example of how bias shows up even for highly credentialed leaders, useful for recognizing patterns and naming the problem.

quotes.topic_title: Being a woman in tech: realities and leverage points
quotes.text: And so my recommendation and what I'd love to say to the industry generally, to women in particular, is curiosity and empowerment have been my path to joy in this sometimes complicated industry.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Condenses her coping-and-progress strategy into a memorable, repeatable principle practitioners can adopt day-to-day.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now, you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers, and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA, and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Highlights a consolidated approach to risk, trust, and compliance automation across multiple standards in one tool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risk.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Emphasizes continuous compliance monitoring paired with reporting and risk tracking as an operational model.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, actionable efficiency claim: using AI to reduce time spent on security questionnaires.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Join thousands of global companies that use Vanta to automate evidence collection, unify risk management, and streamline security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: Gives a specific adoption data point (“thousands”) and a clear set of operational benefits to target (evidence, risk, reviews).

quotes.topic_title: Scrappiness and agency: selling her startup while pregnant
quotes.text: I think you have to be able to do a lot with a little, and I think you have to know where you're getting and, come hell or high water, figure out a way to get there.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A crisp definition of scrappiness as resourcefulness plus relentless execution toward a clear destination.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappiness and agency: selling her startup while pregnant
quotes.text: And this was a very fun example of working my way into the right room, setting myself up for the success that I wanted, and having the backing, the good job, the great product, the outcomes to earn it. But you also have to get yourself in the room.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A practical career/business model: merit matters, but access and deliberate positioning are prerequisites.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappiness and agency: selling her startup while pregnant
quotes.text: I got these two meetings to manifest against each other, and then I walked into that experimentation day and I eyeballed the CFO of Optimizely and I sat in front of him and started pulling up the product and coding at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable tactic for engineering serendipity and creating high-leverage proximity to decision-makers.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappiness and agency: selling her startup while pregnant
quotes.text: A ticking time bomb of a belly is a really good negotiation tactic in a deal.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A counterintuitive negotiation insight: constraints (even personal ones) can increase urgency and improve deal dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Scrappiness and agency: selling her startup while pregnant
quotes.text: Literally, you can fly me out today and back tomorrow, and then I'm not allowed on planes.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A specific example of using a hard deadline to force fast decision-making and close terms efficiently.

quotes.topic_title: The rise of the CPTO: combining product and engineering
quotes.text: I do think you have to be technical to do a role like this.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Sets a clear bar for CPTOs: technical depth isn’t optional if you’re accountable for product outcomes and engineering execution.

quotes.topic_title: The rise of the CPTO: combining product and engineering
quotes.text: But no, actually I spent quite a bit of time on the engineering side, because as somebody who is responsible for the business outcomes of the product, one of the best ways to drive value is having a highly performant engineering team that works on a scalable platform.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Connects business outcomes directly to engineering performance and platform scalability as a primary value lever.

quotes.topic_title: The rise of the CPTO: combining product and engineering
quotes.text: And I just don't think you can do that job if you don't understand how software gets built on a technical level.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A contrarian pushback against the idea that CPTOs can rely purely on delegation and general leadership to run engineering effectively.

quotes.topic_title: The rise of the CPTO: combining product and engineering
quotes.text: So I'm the kind of person that when we're doing a product review, I have the PRD up and GitHub up and I'm comparing both, because I think both sides matter.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice for CPTOs to align product intent with actual implementation details.

quotes.topic_title: The rise of the CPTO: combining product and engineering
quotes.text: Edge teams are by nature much larger than product organizations.
quotes.speaker: Claire Vo
quotes.context: Highlights an org-design reality that changes how leaders should think about operations, ratios, and scaling challenges in a combined role.
